text: our chief international correspondent
Lee's Doucet was recently in Saudi
Arabia she spoke to the country's
Minister for information and culture
Adel al - Rafi about the pressures he
faces no one can deny that between all
the new you always have a kind of
resistance or a kind of different views
I would say but with time if you work on
them together and you work on dialogue
then you can achieve something and some
of the debates or some of the actually
controversial issues over time they
become normal issues people with
technology with gradually Kingdom I'll
give you just an example when the when
TV first appeared in Saudi Arabia it was
controversial nobody in our context and
not the content you know just speaker
because it was a new technology now as
you can see 12 channels and those are
just what the government is is doing and
especially with the understanding if you
allow people to debate and to have a
dialogue and once they realize that this
is not part of thing to harm their
culture or harm their way of life they
tend to accept it especially if you have
that kind of of understanding of the
sensibilities that are there are and you
make it a great debate and a great
dialogue between the older and newer
generation well with me is least asset
our chief international correspondent
that's fascinating leads because
obviously starting to bring in new ideas
and debate is not something that's
easily controlled and this is a state
that likes to be in control yes of
course in this Minister is part of this
generational transfer of leadership he's
36 years old so the second youngest
member of the cabinet brought in
educated in the West to bring in new
ideas in a country where more than 60%
of the population is under the age of 30
and many highly educated who have been
brought up in a very privileged
existence in the oil-rich Kingdom but
Saudi Arabia faces many challenges if
you check some of the recent opinion
polls shows that you know the youth in
Saudi Arabia which has the highest per
capita usage of YouTube and
which er that they are attracted to you
know extremist forces like the so-called
Islamic state so the government has had
to fight back against against that as
well but at least now there you need to
recognize it and to see that they have
to do something about it yeah you could
say they've come rather late to that
well they they have come under criticism
that the kind of puritanical very strict
a version of Islam that is taught in
Saudi Arabia the home of Wahhabi Islam
is part of the problem across the Middle
East which the Saudi authorities
vigorously deny to say it is not not the
same thing you cannot complete what is
what our religion with what's happening
with the so-called Islamic state etc but
I think they are also coping with the
challenges based in many countries quite
frankly but how to reconcile the
aspirations of a young generation at a
time rising unemployment and of course
Saudi Arabia afflicted by oil low prices
but so how do you raise aspirations and
then fulfill them and something that's
really fascinating you mentioned this
Minister is 36 you are talking about a
generational or two generational
switchover and there must be a lot of
debate within government that I guess
we're not privy to about how to move
with the times well it is difficult an
absolute monarchy and them and those who
are in power are you know in the 70s and
80s although some the Minister of
Defense the deputy Crown Princess is now
the youngest defence minister in the
world so they are moving toward that but
a lot of decisions are not taken by
anything approaching democracy it's not
a parliamentary system they don't have
regular elections we saw this month the
first elections municipal balls where
women were allowed to stand and vote so
things move very slowly in Saudi Arabia
very much on Saudi terms they basically
say excuse you know this is our country
we will proceed at our own pace and in
our own time but the pressures are
mounting and they're very much aware of
that it has always been the case that
given pressures from society there's
been enough money to throw at the
pressures to throw at people to stop
them being disaffected to put it very
crudely and of course that's now getting
harder as the economic outlook gets a
little tougher this will be a new
challenge for Saudi Arabia money was
always in in no shortage of money a lot
of lavish spending very very cheap to
live in Saudi Arabia where it took care
of electricity and water now for the
first time they're having to pay for
petrol the subsidies are being
electricity prices are going up water is
going up they've got a very generous
scholarship program will that mean they
have to start cutting the scholarship
program so we'll bite and in democracies
with elected governments you have to
represent the people's aspirations they
don't really have that ability in Saudi
Arabia they say that Twitter is one of
the places where young people engage
with leaders and actually ministers do
respond to young people on Twitter but
is that really enough when there is
going to be a big big question mark over
who decides where the changes we made
and what are the priorities for the
kingdom as it goes forward
